So I really respect Chijiwa and Tsugumo, they love their family with no reason. The film is very political and depressive, their love is the only warming and touching point.

Masaki Kobayashi's "Harakiri" or "Seppuku" is filled with drama and suspense. Kobayashi decided to tell the story in a non-linear style with plenty of flashbacks. This allowed the viewer to remain on edge, filled with skepticism and anticipation throughout the film. This director has no limits. I don't think I have ever had such a reaction to blood and gore in a film as I did in Harakiri. It got me to my feet. I completely respect his decision to show those elements, as they were completely necessary. This choice commanded that the viewer recognize from the very beginning that this was not just a story of life and death but a tale with deeper meaning. Isolationism was the overall theme of this movie, and Kobayashi does a spectacular job of sticking to this. Whenever we see Hanshiro telling his story from the courtyard we are overwhelmed with this sense of isolation, an every man for himself type of feeling.Cinematically speaking, the choices made in this arena felt ironically inviting and apprehensive simultaneously. Kobayashi makes the choice to shoot the majority of the film at kneeling height or eye level, because that is where the majority of people remained throughout the entire film. It is really one of those films that leaves you questioning, which makes sense as the director was prominently known for questioning all things Japanese.

"Harakiri" is a film that was needed to be made by bringing a likely tale of the historic era in the Edo period. The stunning and crisp black and white cinema from the director Masaki Kobayashi showcases the theme of the film and of the samurai with the discipline and orderliness displayed throughout the film. However, there is much more behind the curtain of the so-called samurai. Tsugumo Hanshirō, the hero, or maybe even consider an anti-hero, has a mission to commit harakiri because he has become a shogun and would like an honorable death. The mission at hand isn't really the one the audience or Iyi Clan thought it to be. With a brilliant story and a wonderful battle of Hanshiro and the clan at the end, this movie brings thought provoking elements and a surprising plot twist that will give any more than they expected.

Harakiri Hanshiro developed the cynicism of his character and personality ,that cynicism and emotional narrative touch the principal leader: Saito ,attacking him with his words provoking on him desperation even emotions , Saito lets him to continue with his story even though he has the power as the principal ,just to make the decision to kill him in any moment , but he didn't .Hanshiro in an act of bravery and psychological suicidal character in my visualization. because after all, his principal intention after narrate his history ,was to die . Blinded by his strong and dogmatic beliefs , he attacked against his life as an act of loyalty and the strong belief that exist life after death to meet his daughter ,grandson and son in law . After all he has not nothing to loose anymore ,but first he tried to teach with his history something beyond his blind beliefs and emotional reasons; human side , emotions showing that there's something more than suicide to feed their cultural believes . . . respect for life .

I really enjoyed this Film. You definitely need to know the historical background of Ancient Japan to understand the film. It takes place in a time where thousand of Samurai where out of work and thrown into poverty. It was very interesting to see another cultures perspective on honor and loyalty. I felt bad for the ronins that where poor and had no way to survive. Harakiri is a ritualistic suicide for Samurai in Ancient Japan. This is an honorable ritual. The film tends to jumps around in different points of view throughout the storyline, so make sure you pay attention. What I took away from this movie is that sometimes the traditional ways of respecting authority must be questioned, especially when it comes down to what you believe to be right or wrong.

Where has this film been my whole life?! This incredible tale shows the life of an unemployed Samurai in an impoverished sector of Japan. The Bushido code is challenged, and the true morale code and way of Samurai life is challenged to the core. I was told that I would never forget my first time witnessing an act of Seppuku, when one commits Harakiri by disemboweling themselves with their samurai sword. So far, I haven't. The black and white film technology available at the time of this movies production is a crime against humanity. How I would have loved to seen the rich red colors of the samurai armor, and to visually see the lush green trees in the Iyi Clan courtyard, or the saged yellow grass starving for the suns rays or a drop of water during Hanshiro's duel with the master swordsman. The film is a work of art, and should be treated as such. Sightly harsh and startling audio coupled with dark images and a haunting story line make this film probably something you shouldn't watch alone in the dark.

Review title: Hanshiro is introduced as a Ronin asking the Iyi Clan masters if they would accept his desire to perform harakiri in their courtyard as a dignified samurai.
Review_body: This film is narrated by more than on e person. However the main character, Hanshiro, gets to tell his full story of how and why he got there to the Iyi Clan. There is suspicion from the beginning when he is asked if he really ants to perform harakiri or if he simply wants money or a job. The counselor asks him this and Hanshiro replies the same answer that his son in law, Motome, did when he came in search for an open hand. Through Hanshiro's story telling, we are able to see the true meaning for why he is there; revenge for his lost family. Althpugh his intention is not on killing them, he simply wants them to acknowledge the unethical way they went about with Motome. In the beginning of them movie, the Iyi Clan armor is depicted as honorable, brave and even a little frightening however after the plot uncovers how the samurai retainers acted, the armor becomes an insignificant and worthless statue.

Harakiri is a masterfully constructed period drama by director Masaki Kobayashi. The film is expertly set up and provides the viewer with a thought provoking, entertaining two hours of both brilliant dialogue and suspenseful action. The film starts with the protagonist of the story, Tsugumo Hanshiro (Tatsuya Nakadai), as an out of work Samurai requesting to commit Harakiri (Seppuku) because he feels he wants to end his life honorably instead of poor and hungry. The counselor of the clan tells Hanshiro a story similar to what is happening now and the other samurai's grisly fate to deter him, but Hanshiro remains committed to his cause. The film is told through a series of stories, using flashbacks and narration to move the story along. Kobayashi effectively used the flashbacks and allows the viewer to easily follow the story line while jumping between different stories and timelines. While the acting of Hanshiro and the Counselor is of a higher tier than most, some of the supporting actors fall flat and leave much to be desired. For example, in the film, when Hanshiro is telling a story of his daughter and her husband, the characters end up being a little flat and not living up to their full potential. Their acting wasn't pivotal in the advancement of the story so it didn't deter the viewer's enjoyment of the film.Overall this film was deep and the viewer realized that both the protagonist and antagonist both have their own motivations. I found myself thinking about this film and the messages it conveyed long after I finished watching it. There are parallels that can be drawn with current events and even could cause you to reassess your own moral code. I highly recommend this well-written film.

Harakiri is a great black and white film,the director Masaki Kobayashi gives an insightful look on the after life of a samurai. The story is based through a flashback so the viewer has to figure out who is telling the story which is very different technique but it draws the viewer in. The film is about a ronin which is an ex samurai however, because he is no longer successful and has no family left, he wants to commit seppuku which is the art of cutting in the gut. However, the way the film is structure the viewer sees what he has experience and how his experiences led up to him making this decision. Something that is very interesting is the actor perform his own stunts. The films end in this very organized combat that was actually used with real weapons and everyone was highly train on how and when to throw the weapons and what direction so that it appears very real. Overall, the movie is great and takes the viewer through the journey of a ronin's life.

Mizoguchi does an excellent job at creating a strong willed character that will stop at nothing to expose dogmatic followings of the Bushido code as unnecessary and unethical. I admire Mizoguchi for going against his cultures beliefs in order to showcase his own for others. So often we are quieted by what our religion, parents, culture, etc. expect of us; we are never able to claim our own identity and beliefs in fear of rejection. Hanshiro, who is against the dogmatic version of the Bushido code, is ironically the one samurai who embodies the noble side of it above anyone else. I feel here Mizoguchi was trying to deliver the message that following your own beliefs and "orders" is far more valuable than following others orders. Anyone can be a dogmatic follower only a few can think freely and passionately enough to be a counterforce to wrong acts that are seen as societal norms. You can definitely feel that Mizoguchi was influenced by the French New way in terms of how he decides to tell the story—it's not particularly in chronological order. Instead it is a story that is told through a past story (Motome's experience). By telling both of these stories you can further understand what fueled Hanshiro to be the admirable rebel that he is.

Review title: Today's Good Sucker Punch from the Past
Review_body: Soldier Masaki Kobayashi directed the Jedi-geki piece "Harakiri", which is about a man who is on the quest of committing sepuku (suicide), a respectable death in an honorable place for respectable Samurais. The movie starts out slow with the dialog, because the pace of the scenes and the actors are soothing on a monotone level (I understand that with the Samurais in a sacred place, that is part of their mannerism and culture). However, the more you watch the film, the pace starts to pick up as you listen to the story play on by (there are a series of flashbacks implemented into the scene). As you progress into the film, it turns out that the Samurai is looking for an honorable death, but he is also there to mock the code of the Bushido, and the unbalance that exists within the system that cost him his son in law's life in a horrid way, who he cared for as a son.Kobayashi takes us on a journey about how man, in a corrupted system, tends to either dehumanize us into walking robots, or giving us a choice to find balance in society. I though this was brilliant of him to put this film together, especially since he was a soldier himself, and got persecuted for similar parallel circumstances (not the suicide, but the system of "doing your job" in a military stance). Tatsuya Nakadai (who played Samurai Hanshiro Tsugumo) did a brilliant job and stole the show. There is a spiritual element in the film, but I suggest to watch the film and pay attention to the dialog, because this film will really make you think about our current society today.

While "Harakiri" was not my first experience with Japanese history, culture or cinema, it was still an impacting and enlightening film. While ruthless in nature, "Harakiri" does a wonderful job in conveying the history of ancient Japan, samurais and the Bushido code. While some people's knowledge of samurais only extend as far as the Disney film, "Mulan", "Harakiri" sheds a great deal of light on the underlying meaning behind the truth, strength and honor of the code. With a protagonist that is both relentless and appealing, "Harakiri" delivers special performances all over the board. While it moves a bit slow, there is an undeniable enchantment about this film. The story, while heart-wrenching, is so well done that you come out of it rooting for more. It makes you question history and the way it's perceived, just as I'm sure Mr. Kobayashi intended. With engaging choreography and near-perfect consume and set design, "Harakiri" brings you to a place and time that you otherwise may not have known existed. Kobayashi does a wonderful job at conveying the internal struggle between all characters, men whom have an obligation to their families, and those who have one to their code. This film challenges all the elements of revenge, redefinition and ritual. A job very well done.

Originally titled "Seppuku," "Harakiri" is a 1962 Japanese film directed by Masaki Kobayashi. "Harakiri" is a narrative in nonlinear format, meaning that the order in which the film unfolds is not necessarily the order in which events transpired. I have no knowledge as to whether Tarantino has actually seen this film or cited as an influence, but it is easy to imagine this film as an influence of his, especially in relation to the nonlinear narrative, as well as the role Japanese cinema played on him.The protagonist of the film is Hanshiro, who is a ronin, or a samurai without a lord. The premise of the film is that Hanshiro travels to the house of the Ii clan, where he asks to perform seppuku, which is a type of suicide performed by samurai wherein the samurai disembowels himself with the intent of preserving his honor. The Ii clan's counselor, Saito, agrees to let Hanshiro perform seppuku. Saito tells Hanshiro of another ronin who came there wishing to perform seppuku before him. This is really where things get interesting. To preserve the viewing experience of readers who may not have seen the film yet, I will not delve into many details beyond the initial premise discussed above."Harakiri" is a film I would highly recommend. Essentially, the real message of the film is focused on the consequences of blinding following code or rules and the effect that that type of dogmatism can have. This is a film that will stick with you long after the initial viewing, so be prepared to question any beliefs you may hold afterwards.

While being an important part of Japanese film, this movie keeps the viewer attached to their seat throughout the whole movie. Its intense action scenes and great acting add to its authentic and captivating plot. It tells the story within an important time of Japanese history- the Tokugawa era. The viewer is able to see how it was to live in Japan during this era and the lifestyle in Japanese culture. It also conveys an important and inspiring lesson of honor, respect, betrayal, and morals. Its dramatic twists and revealing scenes make the film worth watching. The movie shows the life of ronins during the Tokugawa era and how it felt to leave behind the samurai life. The essence of samurai culture is presented in the film's theme and brings the viewer to a new understanding of this culture.

A classic, surviving the test of time -- made in 1962 about 17th century people. Here in 2005, we still watch and discuss the film and the issues that it raises. Tsugumo Hanshiro, a middle-aged ronin formerly serving a clan abolished by the Shogunate, appears at the Ii clan gate. He wishes to commit seppuku rather than live on in poverty. In his inner headquarters, Saito Kageyu, the chief retainer, bemoans the fact that hordes of starving ronin have been making similar requests at clan gates; most have wanted handouts rather than to actually commit seppuku. Kageyu suspects the same of Hanshiro. Kageyu attempts to discourage Hanshiro. He tells a tale of another ronin from the same abolished clan, Chijiiwa Motome. Motome had appeared a few months earlier, with a request, but had carried bamboo sword blades  the clan members had been enraged. As an example to other scrounging ronin, particularly those without real blades, the clan decided to force Motome to commit seppuku with his own bamboo wakizashi. Hanshiro tells his own life story. The film shows us some historical background. Thousands of ex-retainers had been thrown out of their positions, made into ronin, by the Shogunate's abolishing of clans. In the rigid class system (samurai, farmers, artisans, merchants), these displaced ex-retainers had no place at all, being forced into marginal subsistence. Most trades (because they required long periods of apprenticeship) were out for most ronin. Many ronin became outlaws or obtained bodyguard positions for gangsters. If law-abiding, they were able to teach in schools for commoner children. Or become piecework artisans; they could contract with wholesalers (who also lent money) to make fans, umbrellas, insect cages, ink brushes, and the like. Even as most ronin had to fend for themselves in this netherworld, they still were to carry the two swords of their original rank, and to uphold their obligations. Hanshiro and his daughter Miho make umbrellas and fans to sell to wholesalers for a pittance; Hanshiro is in debt to one of the wholesalers. Motome teaches commoner children and receives a minimal wage for his work. Miho and Motome marry and have a son. All goes well until sickness strikes. Miho contracts consumption and the child contracts a fever. Neither Hanshiro nor Motome can afford a doctor. Motome attempts to get a laborer job (which pays more than teaching does) and runs straight into job discrimination: "no starving ronin need apply." Motome sells his sword blades at a pawnshop, obtaining bamboo blades to wear inside his sword fittings, not an uncommon practice; some ronin (and some low-ranked clan samurai) desperately needed money. And yet, the sword was considered to be "the soul of the bushi." A bushi who sold his blades had to appear to wear the badge of his rank. The bamboo blades were available, thus no one would know of the despicable act of having sold his "soul" for money.But Motome has not received enough; he still cannot afford a doctor. So Motome decides on something more desperate: to appear at a clan gate, with his hidden bamboo blades, in order to request seppuku -- with the actual intention of receiving a handout to get a doctor for his wife and child. The Ii clan officials have decided differently. The scene where Motome must commit seppuku with his bamboo wakizashi is one of the most harrowing scenes ever filmed. Motome is utterly humiliated, surrounded by the Ii clan retainers, with Onodaka Hikokuro, his assigned second preaching on how the sword is the soul of the samurai, the bamboo sword is what is appropriate for Motome, and so forth. While Motome painfully carries forth. Hikokuro refuses Motome's request to cut off his head and end the ritual's mockery, so Motome ends it himself, biting off his tongue. Hanshiro has realized -- too late -- that he had never dared to even consider selling his own sword blades to help out the family. The scene when he is confronted with Motome's body and the truth of what has happened is truly gut-wrenching, as Hanshiro weeps and slams down his "useless tokens" that he had clung to. Hanshiro reveals his own secret  he has used his "useless tokens" to avenge Motome's death. He has tracked down the three Ii retainers who were most responsible for Motome's death. The final duel between Hanshiro and Onodaka Hikokuro is absolutely stunning. Instead of taking the lives of these three, Hanshiro has taken their topknots. And while Kageyu has preached to Hanshiro about samurai honor, these three swordsmen have hidden themselves away, claiming sickness to cover up their own shame, while their topknots grow back. Kageyu cannot deal with Hanshiro's revelations. He commands his men to slaughter Hanshiro. Hanshiro fights back gamely, taking four of the Ii clan retainers and wounding several more. In a symbolic scene, he tears down the ancestral armor of the Ii clan. Some Ii clansmen use their rifles against Hanshiro, but Hanshiro sticks his own sword into his belly, committing seppuku as he has pledged to do. In the end, Kageyu fashions a cover-up of the entire event; mysterious plagues have hit the Ii clan and a number of their retainers, including Onodaka, have died of "illness" rather than by the blade of an impoverished hungry ronin. This film raises many issues. It is Kobayashi's impassioned protest against rigidly militaristic societies that uphold hypocritical codes of "bushido" while disdaining what that term really means. The film is also like a Greek tragedy, with a character (Tsugumo Hanshiro) possessing the tragic flaw of his own pride -- which in the end, he must pay for with his life. Which he does in a heroic way. This film doesn't just recount the oppression of poor people. It shows the strength that these poor people have, the choices that they make as individuals, refusing to just bow down and be mere victims of their society.

Hanshiro Tsugumo, a destitute, out of work Samurai, presents himself at the home of his feudal lord and asks permission to use the elegant courtyard to perform ritual suicide, or Harakiri, thereby assuring himself an honorable death. But the Counselor who considers his request is suspicious of Hanshiro's motives, thinking the Samurai might simply be preying on his sympathies in the hopes of securing employment or being paid off and sent away. It turns out the Counselor is right to be suspicious, but very wrong about Hanshiro's motives.This movie is about the Samurai, but there aren't any elaborate battle scenes with flashing swords and bloody deaths (there is one difficult death scene). Harakiri is a mystery, almost a thriller, an intricately woven, ticking time bomb of a film. Tatsuya Nakadai (a highly respected Japanese actor) plays Hanshiro with an understated swagger, intimidating in spite of his impoverished state, but when the camera lingers on his face, we can see heartbreak in his eyes – a deep pain that has led him to question the nobility of the Samurai code.Beautifully shot in black and white, wonderfully acted, altogether a great story told by a great filmmaker (director Masaki Kobayashi). Won the Special Jury Prize at Cannes, and was nominated and/or won a number of other acting, directing and writing awards.

Peace in 17th century Japan causes the Shogunate warrior clans to dissolve, throwing thousands of samurai out of work and into poverty. An honorable end to this fate under the samurai code is ritual suicide, or hara-kiri (self-inflicted gutting). An older warrior, Hanshiro Tsugumo (Tatsuya Nakadai) seeks admission to the home of a feudal lord to commit the act. There, he learns of the fate of his son-in-law, a young samurai who sought work at home, but was savagely forced to commit traditional hara-kiri in a painful way with a blind bamboo blade. In flashbacks, the samurai tells the tragic story of his son-in-law and how he was forced to sell his royal sword to support his sick wife and son. Tsugumo, therefore, starts a tense confrontation of revenge against the house.

Review title: The better you know a man, the better you understand his motives.
Review_body: Kobayashi's "Harrakiri" easily enthralls the viewer through the tale of a ronin named Hanshiro who enters the house of Iyi to commit harrakiri- This is a story full of plot-twists and "aha" moments that will leave you in awe. Harrakiri was slow-paced and slightly confusing in the beginning, but that was the beauty of it. As soon as I put the missing pieces together, I felt fully-connected to each character. There was such complexity and tension throughout the film, it was almost nauseating. In the beginning, we are shown the symbol of the Iyi clan- an empty suit of armor that embodies power and integrity; the essence of grandeur. It is Hanshiro's storytelling throughout the film that shows how counselor Saito of the Iyi Clan is completely dehumanized beyond reason. Counselor Saito refuses to have the clan exploited for money or clothes so he tells the tale of a ronin named Motome and his attempt to commit harrakiri with a bamboo sword. Hanshiro tells his side of the story: The heart-breaking story of Motome who did not have enough money to help his dying wife Miho and son Kingo. Counselor Saito knew he took it too far but he refused to acknowledge that he did anything wrong; he was simply following the code(the code is greater than life itself). Acknowledgement of such a thing could cause complete chaos and would make others question the validity of the bushido code and the Iyi Clan. Finally, once chaos had erupted in the house of Iyi, we are again shown the symbol of the Iyi Clan- an empty suit of armor exposed to be completely hollow and void of all honor it once held.

The complexity of the story is unmatched. The depth of the main character is unmatched. Anyone who loves cinema will be completely satisfied after watching it. I can't give it a perfect 10, but it was darn close.

Review title: Hara-kiri is a film about facades, adherence to rules and, above all, about the true meaning of honor.
Review_body: The pacing of Hara-kiri is slower and more contemplative than most films made in the West, but the build up pays off like a punch to the gut when things are revealed to us. The story is lean despite its 132 minute running time. There are no subplots not directly related to the story, which charges forward to its conclusion without distraction, never veering from its path. The most honorable character in Hara-kiri turns out to be Motome Chijiwa, who spends most of the film being portrayed as a coward, a liar, and a cheat for pretending to want to commit hara-kiri. A reversal of roles (or, more accurately, a reversal in our perceptions) occurs as we slowly discover that Motome did what he did in an effort to make money to support his ill and impoverished family. His character and motives do not change throughout the story, but our perceptions of him change from that of a coward, to that of a brave hero. The decision of Motome to sell the blades of his swords to support his family (which means grave dishonor for a samurai) turns out to be honorable. In light of this, Hanshiro's insistence on not selling his blades in spite of his family's suffering, illness, and subsequent death seems cowardly and foolish.The structure of Hara-kiri intercuts back and fourth between the past (Motome's hara-kiri) and the present (Hanshiro's hara-kiri). At first, the two stories seem completely unrelated (other than that they both involve Ronin requesting to commit hara-kiri). As the two stories progress, we learn that the two men not only knew each other, but were related by marriage. We finally learn that Hanshiro is there to restore honor to the memory of Motome, and to show the Iyi clan the error of their ways.Hanshiro tells the Iyi samurai not to be so quick to judge others, for they may soon be faced with the same fate. This could not be more true. They are also samurai, just like the struggling ronin who showed up at their door to perform hara-kiri. At any time, their house could fall, just as the others did, and then they themselves would become wandering ronin, struggling to survive and to support their families. Hanshiro tells them, "How can those who never wanted for food or clothing understand (the ronin's) misery?"We cannot pass judgment on the antagonists without also seeing the snap judgments that we ourselves make. In this sense, Hara-kiri holds up a mirror to it's audience. We never know someone's full story and reasons for doing something, and therefore, are in no place to make judgments about their character. Hanshiro says to the Iyi clan samurai, "Let them laugh all they want. Who can fathom the depths of another man's heart?""After all, this thing we call samurai honor is ultimately nothing but a façade." Samurai "honor" is merely pageantry. Motome set an example for real, genuine honor. The samurai genuinely believe that they are doing the right thing as they desperately cling to their written code of honor. They are blinded and bound by their own strict set of rules (the Bushido code).I feel conflicted about Saito. Yes, he shows much more humanity than Hikokuro's strict and ruthless adherence to dogma, but Saito sees, on some level, that this is wrong. Yet he is in charge of the Iyi clan and still refuses to stop it (although he is the one in the position to do so). Yes, it would create a stir, but I think it makes him the most despicable character: the one who sees something is wrong, and has the power to stop it, yet does nothing about it.At the end, Hanshiro breaks the armor statute (which represents the samurai rules, doctrine, and façade) and then commits hara-kiri before being shot with a gun by the Iyi samurai (they could not defeat him with a sword, ten against one).The final shots of the film include the leitmotif of the journal. In the beginning, it is simply the act of creating a record; at the end, it is the proliferation of lies which survives. The written historical account is falsified to preserve the façade of honor, and to (at least temporarily) keep the Iyi clan in power.

This film tells the meaning of the honor of the Samurai and the Bushido code that they lived by through an interesting way of using multiple flashbacks. Director Masaki Kobayashi leaves audiences questioning what was more important; for a man to stand for his own pride, or leave pride behind to stand for his loved ones.Being born and raised in Japan myself, after watching this film I was left thinking deeply about the true meaning of honor. At first glance, Motome Chijiiwa seems like a coward, lying to the Iyi clan asking to commit Seppuku as an attempt to get money to be asked to leave. However, through Hanshiro's story-telling, we find out that Motome was only committing such actions to pay for a doctor to save his sick family. In my opinion, I think Motome's actions are justified and he can be considered an honorable Samurai. Fighting for the lives of others is more honorable than fighting for one's own pride. In the end, the Iyi clan members who took pride in and lived by the Bushido code so much were the ones that tarnished the code themselves. In the beginning of the film, an Iyi clan red armor is shown as a representation of an honorable and glorious spirit. In the end, the same armor is shown. However, this time it seems empty, as if there was nothing for the Iyi clan to stand for anymore.I give this film a 7 out of 10 because of the unique way the story unfolds, as well as the topic that had me thinking for days.

Review title: Harakiri: Lessons on how NOT to act as leader.
Review_body: "Harakiri" is a sophisticated film that critiques the Samurai of the Tokugawa era around 1630. The order in which this story is told is crucially important to the way the viewer perceives each character on an individual basis. Although the film starts with a Ronin desiring to commit Harakiri, known as Hanshiro, it quickly turns into a flashback when counselor Saito tells the story of a man named Motome Chijiwa. The story reveals how Motome dies, but is irrelevant until Hanshiro tells his life story just before he is about to commit Harakiri. After hearing Hanshiro's detailed story, the camera angles and placement begin to play a key role in the message behind this film. Not only does it become clear that Hanshiro is at the Iyi temple with a hidden agenda, but we also start to see close up shots of Saito who is becoming deeply affected by the story being told. It sparks a possibility that maybe Saito will understand that he made a poor decision in having Motome killed, and that he should apologize to Hanshiro. On the contrary, Saito not only doesn't apologize, but he calls for an even harsher punishment on Hanshiro, thinking that he was some kind of crazy psychopath. Listening to Hanshiro's story, it made sense as to why Hanshiro was so angry, considering he may have only wanted to hear Saito admit he made a mistake. Saito is so caught up in his role as a counselor and Samurai master that he is evidently incapable of publicly expressing feelings of human emotion. This demonstrates how easily humans tend to abuse power, and how Saito cannot give in to Hanshiro's story that clearly points out Saito's mistake."Harakiri" is not just about the life of Samurai, but also the levels extremity in which they abide by the Boshido code. It's an interesting paradox how these samurai in the Iyi temple are so quick to judge the two Ronin who walk into their temple, yet as a viewer we tend to catch ourselves doing the same thing. There is a wide range of samurais in this film, some who are extremely dogmatic towards the Boshido code, and others who maneuver their way around it. Director Kobayashi cleverly points out the idea of humanism in cinema as it becomes the contrast to the Boshido code. Humanism shows how humans are what really matter most, and he demonstrates this, for example, with the character Hikokuro. This extremely dogmatic samurai has his hairpiece cut off in a battle with Hanshiro, which for samurai is worse than death itself, yet, Hikokuro still waits a few days before he commits Harakiri. Why? Well it raises the notion that pure and absolute dogma is a double standard in our society and is not possible for humanity. This film focuses on the significance of how history takes place in our world and how power is ultimately the factor that determines our fate. In "Harakiri" it was the role of Saito's power that created the entire plot and storyline for this film, and ends with a sense of ambiguity towards the significance of the samurai. This derived from witnessing the armor in the beginning with a striking and powerful presence, almost as if it were a spiritual god, and then seeing how in the end it is torn apart and put back together, as if it were something so insignificant as hanging a picture back on the wall. The metaphor of the janitors cleaning up after the battle leading to Hanshiro's death is such a large metaphor for the samurai culture and how so much can occur within their temples and how seemingly unimportant it tends to feel after the fact. Although the film has a dramatic plot, it is the critique on powerful people in society that transforms this film into a something more than your typical samurai battle movie.

Review title: Tradition vs. Humanism: the revaluation of dogmas
Review_body: Tradition vs. Humanism: the revaluation of dogmas and inevitability of progress Having participated in kendo, the art of Japanese swordsmanship, for a good decade, I am somewhat familiar with the importance of tradition and discipline within the samurai culture. Of course, the tradition has lessened in it's severity overtime, but we still respect and remember it's importance and time and place in the culture. Watching the movie "Harakiri" I couldn't help but question the dogmatism of the men of the Iyi clan. In the beginning of the movie I felt slightly delightful that Motome was being teased and tortured. I judged him without even thinking about his situation. Later, finding out more details of his personal life, I felt sorry and guilty for feeling almost enjoyment for his forced suicide. Passing judgment on Motome without even knowing or trying to know what he went through shows the audience that, we as a people, it is in our nature to take the point of view of those who are telling the story. This also makes a statement on how the history we know might not be true. It could be biased by the people who wrote it. This is proved at the end where Counselor Saito rewrites the history and covers up the incidents that occurred within the Iyi house. Professor and Director Salvador Carrasco states that, "Meta history is what we get. We were privy to what happened even though Saito fabricates the history at the end." Knowing that, how can we judge or even believe the facts of history that we know now?The discipline of the followers of the Bushido code shows how sometimes, exceptions of the code should be made for the greater good. Take Motome for example: he was a respected samurai but had to resort to selling his pride as one to save his family. If the Iyi clan had the decency, the humanism to respect Motome's request or even ask him why, things might have been different. But because of their headstrong attitude and pride to follow the code, Motome and his family are inevitably doomed. Through their dogmatic attitude and self-righteousness, they lacked humanism. It is in our human nature to become greedy, pompous, and abusive when we have power. When the three retainers of the Iyi clan call in sick for having had their top buns cut off, it shows that when power is taken away, so is their self-righteousness and pride.Also, In the beginning of the film, a contrasted shogun armor is shown. It represented power and something bigger but towards the end, it represented something else. Seeing the corruption and abuse of power, the fabrication of history, I can't help but see a meaningless, empty shell of a tradition that used to mean so much more. Overall, the human condition is constantly being questioned throughout the film. With it's print-like composition and symmetrical settings clean shots and simplicity,, the solemnity and seriousness of the film is exemplified.

Harakiri is the first Japanese film I have seen and it is definitely not for the lazy. Be ready to read subtitles at the speed of light and pay attention because if you don't you run the risk of missing out on a whole lot of plot and information. The film starts out slow, following a ronin and his family as they struggle through hard times that include unemployment, sickness, loss and a little bit of love and selflessness to even everything out. At times it can be a little confusing but if you pay attention to the characters you'll have no problem putting together all the pieces of the puzzle. The theme of this movie is relatable across every culture. You feel for the characters and the situation they are in and when you find out that the family has sold everything of value they own, even the blades of Motome's swords, your heart aches for them because you know it still isn't enough. And finally for a nice spin at the end, history is rewritten and it will leave you questioning everything you've been told. An all around amazing story that is definitely worth watching.

I had never seen a Japanese film before I saw Harakiri. For an introduction to Japanese cinema, I was greatly impressed by Kobayashi's accomplishment in making this complex film look effortlessly simple. At first, I thought that this film would be a typical period piece just set in Japan but that was an ignorant assumption that I made. The film follows the story of two ronins (samurai), Motome and Hanshiro, during the Tokugawa era. They each, at separate times, ask to commit harakiri (suicide) at the Iyi clan house with similar background stories. Half way through the film, the story comes around that these two ronins are related. The film's plot not only symbolizes the end of the samurai way of life, but also presents a greater meaning of humanism vs dogmatism and the corruptive nature of power. The film makes us, the audience, aware of our own humanistic, dogmatic and corrupt traits by following Hanshiro's explanation to who he is and who Motome was. Although at first, we see Motome come to the Iyi clan to commit harakiri, we also see that he does everything in his power to save his family and what his intentions were originally, making him the most honorable of samurai. The Iyi clan persecute him due to regime than considering the reasoning for his suicide. The clan represents the dogmatic samurai that think with their heads rather than their hearts. This shows the corruptive nature of power and stagnation. The film brings to attention our own ignorant assumptions that make us draw parallels between our moral code and that of the samurai code. Stylistically it is beautifully composed with balance and precision. The plot is perfectly complex yet easily understood, reflecting Japanese tradition, as not to obscure the meaning. Every scene has a deep significance and every element has a symbolic value that truly makes this film one of the best I have ever seen.

Harakiri dives into many different themes such as perception, judgement, and loyalty. When the story of Motome is told the viewer begins pass judgement onto him and his motives. Later on we find out that his motives are essentially pure. Considering the deeper themes of the movie we see in the end a metaphor for what happens when humanism comes second to loyalty to a code. The film uses one of the most creative forms of story telling to convey a complex and deep message. The complexity of the plot adds a deep element of surprise that provokes thought. Kobayashi uses characters to represent extremes of personalities as well institutions. The film falls short many times in keeping the audiences attention, and misses out on many opportunities to capitalize on the sudden shifts in plot and tone. This consistent variable makes the film a very long winded two hours. By the end of the film you might feel as though your mind was subjected to something far more exhausting than watching a film. If you manage to power through many forced emotions from the actors and over dramatic timing than you can actually begin to appreciate the deeper themes conveyed through the story telling of the film. Kobayashi masterfully crafted scenarios in the film that made you like many of the other characters within it, because neither of you know the whole truth until you are hit with it. This film goes through great lengths humanize certain characters while limiting itself in passing judgement on others. You begin to learn that when everyone follows a certain philosophy the difference in perspective and interpretation can mean everything. Over all this film uses many different clever tactics to add depth to action and entertaining gore. Although much of the pacing of the film and cinematography leave something to be desired this is still an extremely well executed and intelligent film.
