This is just a movie about the kind of guy everyone wishes they were. A man of honor with nothing to lose, carrying out justice. Probably almost half of the movie is flashbacks or a story in a story, but when it's pulled off, it's just the most intriguing thing to watch. It's easy to jump to conclusions in this movie, but it's like your whole impression of a character changes every 20 minutes. It's unimaginable as to how much controversy this film caused in Japan, especially coming from a Japanese filmmaker, but it really makes you think about the samurai culture and their position in society. It's truly one of the greatest examples of exploring humanism there is. Every character, even the protagonist, have their flaws that probably cost them a lot, but you're not left not understanding any character. You really can see the story from everyone's very different perspectives. It explores ideas that society never really stops to think about, like when is compassion more important than pride, or how literally should you really take things, and when do you really start abusing power. It doesn't force a message or moral on its audience, but just makes you stop to think about them, and show you what can happen when you take one side of it. You can watch this movie looking for every detailed meaning in it, or just watch it because it's a guy with nothing to lose and a lot of skills, going out for justice. Either way it's great and really a true example of what Japanese culture has brought to filmmaking.

Do not Hurry up to judgeAfter the civil wars in Japan a lot of samurais lost their jobs and became ronins. Some ronins travleled across Japan looking for jobs and others decided to commit harakiri (when a samurai kills himself with his own sword)Hanshiro, a ronin, comes to the Iyi house and asks to commit sepuku. The counselor tells him a story about a ronin Motome that lied that he wanted to commit sepuku. He was caught and forced not only to commit it, but to do it with his bamboo sword. Hanshiro listens to the story and insists that his intentions are true. The ceremony begins and Hanshiro tells the other side of Motome's story...The movie is incredible! It holds your attention from the beginning to the very end. I loved the way Masaki Kobayashi makes the viewers totally change their opinions about the characters throughout the movie. For example, at first I didn't sympathize Motome. I thought he was a liar, a quitter and he didn't deserve to be a samurai (and so did the Iyi house), but when Hanshiro tells Motome's story I felt the opposite. I thought what a brave man, how much he loved his family, he even sold his sword (which is extremely important for a samurai; "a sword is a samurai's soul"; and it is very important detail that Hanshiro didn't even think about selling his sword and he really regrets that).I loved how Kobayashi shows Hanshiro's revenge not buy killing those three samurai's, but buy embarrassing them, buy cutting off their topknots (for a samurai loosing his topknot in a battle is worse than death).The two characters that are very important in the movie are the counselor and Hikokuro. Hikokuro is this true, dogmatic samurai that implicitly follows the rules of the Bushido code (which in the end is actually a book of lies). He is tough, strong and disciplined. A lot of viewers thought that he was sadistic, because of the harakiri scene, but I don't think so. He was a real samurai, that believed and followed every word in the Bushido code, and he considered people who disobeyed the code disgusting and weak. That's why he hated Motome and that's why he respected Hanshiro. Saito, the counselor, is another strong character in "Harakiri". He is the opposite of Hikokuro. He is a samurai, but first of all he is a humanist. He definitely understands what Hanshiro was saying, and I'm sure he felt sorry for him and his family, and I think he really regrets what they did to Motome, but at the same time he is a counselor. He is the head, the leader of the Iyi house, and if he brakes down, than the whole house will go down. That is why he ordered to kill Hanshiro, he needed to protect the honor of the Iyi house.It is very important to watch the harakiri scene (yes, girls, it's pretty graphic, but try to do it). I loved the way Kobayashi contrasts the reactions of Hikokuro, that is angry and doesn't feel any sympathy watching Motome suffer, he didn't even strike of his head, he was waiting for Motome to finish the harakiri cross; and the counselor, who is absolutely shocked and terrified, but doesn't say a word, because he can't, he has to prove that everyone will be treated like this "you come to commit harakiri, we will make sure you do it".My favourite scene is when the counselor makes up a story that will be the official record of what happened. Kobayashi really showed that this book, these ideal rules for samurai's are simply nothing, just a bunch of lies. It's all about appearance, and in fact it's all useless, it's just the illusion of perfection. It really made me question a lot about our lives and especially our history. How many "official" records like these do we have? And are the rules and appearances really worth it, or it's all just an illusion of perfection?

Harakiri is an example of expansion into the depths ones self and beliefs. It makes a statement that opens up the the possibility to question what is the truth and what is made to look like the truth. A true tale that dives into the minds of men and their actions that define history. Harakiri also shows the beliefs of the samurai and the double standards they put upon people and the true hypocrisy of those in power and how they are abel to alter and manipulate events to their own accord. It is also the journey of one man's attempts for revenge and to redeem the honor of his family and to bring the unjust treatment of his family into the light. It is a movie that leaves you with the feeling of bewlilderment and the felling to question and wonder what rally is the truth and what is the fiction that people want us to believe.

Review title: The best Japanese movie I have seen.
Review_body: Hara-Kiri film confused me but it was all clear in the half of it. Its one of those films that the viewer has to pay close attention starting from the beginning to end. Hara-Kiri is about the life of a true Samurai. Its suspense, action, love and revenge in a way. In the first minutes of the film I saw it as if it was about two men going to the Iyi Clan in the same day to ask for help but it was clear when the main character is the one telling the story of the other guy. That was a big twist. The director Kobayashi did a unique style in which tricks the mind for the viewer to think this way. It also shows the humanity in each character in their expressions and thoughts. At the end this film said to me to not judge someone look and to do whats feels right and not what a rule said, meaning of who is really a real human. Emotionally it affected me when the wife cries for her husband because of a pass experience. Then when the main character fights with the Samurais, I wanted him to take revenge towards all but it does not happen. Its another film in which makes you question the history of a country.

In my point of view Hara-kiri was a tremendous movie where surrealism was well perform, where I was able to experiment the feeling of being there because of the good engagement between the Camera conflict of angles (high and low). However, the way Hara-kiri was perform it lead to cruelty and brutal for me. Motome, Hanshiro and the rest of samurai that live in Iyi clan followed the Bushido code which was pure, unique because it was their religion and believes. Also for those who were decided in heart to committed Hara-kiri, they believe it was an honor to die this way. In other hand, I choose to talk about Motome because the scene where he committed Hara-kiri was the most that make me believe on what was happening and the reason why they were doing those kind of rituals. This scene was so pragmatic, it even make me feel the pain Motomo was going trough till the end of his death

Harakiri put in perspective on how most of our world works on knowing and telling the truth. How in society some will have a dogmatic view on certain laws that leave no room for a humanistic approach. This movie has also shown me that maybe not everyone, history or in the present, is not who they seem. There were good samurai out there who really were respectful and honorable and ones who weren't. That there is no shame in putting your dignity on the line for the people you love and protect. It made me feel as though there is still hope for a conscious/humanistic way of doing things, and that maybe there is still a chance as a society to behave as such. As a bonus I really loved the samurai duals because there was something respectful and honorable about them. The movie itself was great none the less.

Review title: A Quick Look Into Dogmatic Interpretation of the Bushido Code
Review_body: This movie is absolutely amazing. This film gives us insight to the Tokugawa Era of Japan in a very interesting way. Masaki Kobayashi tells an amazing tale of the plight between maintaining samurai ideals and humanistic ethics, we see this through the literal interpretation of the samurai code (the Bushido code) throughout the movie. What really stuck out to me was how hell bent Hikokuro was to make Motome commit seppuku without the grace period, no one cared to hear the back story to understand why Motome needed this period, and when Hanshiro was able to articulate the story to Saito (the counselor) although Saito seemed to be very impacted by the story, he had to uphold the ideals of the Bushido Code even if it meant the harsh self- mutilation of Motome with the bamboo swords.Not only was Hikokuro hell bent on making Motome commit seppuku, but he made sure Motome used the bamboo swords. Hikokuro fills in as Motome's second (to deliver the final blow) but when Motome does not do a "good enough" job Hikokuro refuses to deliver the final blow, so Motome must bite his tongue off to kill himself. This is in all ways the most dogmatic interpretation of the Bushido code because he wants everything to do be done the "samurai way" when in fact he does not.Hikokuro is a great example of a double standard in this movie, he forces Motome to commit seppuku with the bamboo swords, but when it comes to his topknot getting cut off he postpones his own seppuku because he does not want to die quite yet.Lastly we see the Bushido code upheld with such divinity towards the end. Hanshiro kills some of the people at the mansion because he is ordered to be killed and when it comes to writing the account of their deaths, Saito says to say that they died of sickness to not tarnish the Bushido code.Overall this movie was very well made and i really enjoyed watching it. This movie gives us two very different ideas of the character Motome (from scum to honorable) in the beginning and end, which i think is an example of Kobayashi's film genius.

"Harakiri" is a revolutionary Kobayashi masterpiece set in the early days of the Tokugawa Era, when Japan experienced a time of relative peace and Samurai and Ronin alike felt a new wave of challenges that start off the battlefield. The story follows a particular Ronin (or "Unemployed Samurai"), named "Motome", as he requests to commit Harakiri or "Seppuku", a Japanese form ritual suicide, in the valorous House of Iyi. Kobayashi demonstrates his creative power and pure ingenuity in Harakiri as the story unfolds and he raises questions about honor, the Bushido code, the human condition, Samurai, the concept of power and how it affects those who wield it, and Japan's own identity as it emerges from the ever changing world of the post World War II period. Unlike other films about Japan's past and the Samurai in mainstream cinema, Harakiri questions the views of the Samurai and how they may have acted throughout history. For example, although "The Last Samurai" was well received in Japan, some viewers such as Tomomi Katsuta felt its honorable portrayal of the Samurai was incompatible with contemporary views, and that Japanese views of the Samurai are different, stating "Our image of Samurai is that they were more corrupt." For example, Samurai were permitted to kill common folk on site if they so much as gave them a dirty or disrespectful look. "Harakiri" does away with the fairy tale portrayals of Samurai that we often see, reflecting more of who they were and how power can corrupt all."Harakiri" will not disappoint, and I was pleasantly surprised with how it is capable of reaching all audiences, not just domestic ones. The fact that Kobayashi questions the human condition and how people of all origins sometimes handle power, honor, and cultural traditions, makes "Harakiri" and instant classic for anyone who watches it.

Harakiri is one of my favorite films since I have seen it. The directing has a very elegant feel and in some parts it feels as if you were actually there. This is one of those films that slowly and unexpectedly unfolds as you watch it. I found myself switching my feelings about certain characters as the movie went on. In the beginning, you are kind of forced to feel a certain way but gradually after that, you start to learn and understand what is actually happening. In each scene you learn something new and after each scene you just want to keep watching more and more. At the end of the film you can't help to think about the way some people live and the extreme moral codes they live by. Not only that but how some things are kept unsaid just to retain some type of order within that culture. Things like that happen all the time. People cover up the truth and flaws so that the code can remain the same and that others will still follow it. You can only imagine the amount of information that hasn't been passed on throughout the centuries due to that kind of reasoning. Overall, I loved this movie and it kept me on my toes throughout. After you think you start to know the story better, you are fed more and more information which keeps the film interesting from start to finish. Definitely a must see!

Review title: Harakiri eloquently portrays the struggle between morality and politics
Review_body: Harakiri is an astounding achievement as its influence can be seen in countless replications of its signature plot structure. The characters are slow to develop as their intentions and encounters take place in what feels like real-time over the course of flashbacks. Once their intention is learned, the film erupts with a bloody moral battle over the blindness caused by dogmatism and the corruption of power. What is so unique to Kobayashi's masterpiece is his ability to paint the main conflicting characters with enough humanity wherein you are not able to identify "the good guy" until near the ending of the film. Both are viewed in a sympathetic light with their own reasons for their actions being displayed as just and reasonable. This film will make you completely reevaluate your conception of samurai films.

Review title: Watch this Fascinating and Moving Story Unfold
Review_body: It is fascinating to watch the narrative unfold in this Japanese period drama set during a time of relative peace when Samurai were not actively employed as warriors and so many were disenfranchised "ronin" seeking to eke out a living and a meaningful existence.Beautifully shot in black and white and masterfully showing Japanese restraint in its pacing, the film examines the Samurai Bushido (honor) code. But, as a proud ronin named Hanshiro recounts (often through flashbacks) his moving personal story to the Samurai of the House of Iyi, the story unfolds in unexpected ways and we get an opportunity to stare into the souls of those proud Samurai. We also get the opportunity to asses where true honor lies. Is it honorable to adhere to the expected rules and rituals, or is it more honorable to reassess the rules as times of change and to let go of rigidity to show compassion to fellow humans in need?

Review title: Correct the Wrongdoing by Acknowledging It First
Review_body: Rectitude, courage, benevolence, respect, honesty, honor, and loyalty are the seven virtues of Bushido, the spirit that Japanese people value the most. What the counselor of the clan, Saito, did at the end of the movie clearly violates the samurai code because he tells his people to lie about what really happens under the roof of Li Clan. I can't help relating Saito's action to today's Japan's. According to the news, the Prime Minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe, just visited Yasukuni Shrine where 14 of these Japanese Class-A war criminals are paid respects as heroes. In fact, Japanese Government has never admitted that it invaded China and other Asian countries during World War II. Also the government denies the fact that Japanese soldiers committed massacre in Nanking where about 300,000 people were brutally killed. What is the most terrifying and hurting thing is that that period of history is completely altered in some textbooks in Japan saying that Japan was fighting back because other parts of Asia was invading Japan. Personally speaking, I admire the culture of Samurai. And I have always considered the spirit presented by those honorable warriors symbolizes Japan and Yamato people. At the same time, I also believe in humanity. I don't think that any human-made rules can surpass the deep kindness endowed in every individual's heart, which is completely beyond nationality as well as ethnicity. If I ever had a chance to talk to Saito in the movie, I would say: "Please correct the wrongdoing by first acknowledging it."

Review title: Rewriting history to glorify the victors
Review_body: This movie elegantly portrays how history is written by the victors. Kobayashi's soul and personality shine through in his depiction of his experience in the war. Kobayashi flips our emotions so thoroughly and effortlessly throughout the film.He starts and ends the movie with the same scene of a coat of armor, but our emotions and feelings toward the coat of armor couldn't be any more opposite. The way we view the armor in the beginning of the movie as opposed to the end is a great reflection on how we feel about the entire Iyi clan and almost a backwards parallel to how we feel about Motome as the story progresses. At the beginning of the movie we see the armor and it seems to have a life of its own. It's incredibly imposing and you feel as if it is magical or almost godlike and you're just watch, waiting for it to come to life or to see that there's actually someone inside. Though the movie ends with the same exact shot, because of all you have learned about the Iyi can, their symbol seems as hollow as they do. The armor just feels empty, lifeless, and fake. You take the armor for what it really is, a covering or a cloak with nothing behind it. It's interesting how our emotions travel in the opposite direction with regards to Motome. Prior to receiving Hanshiro's story, the audience feels the same way towards Motome and draws the same conclusions about him that the Iyi clan does. However, as Hanshiro's story continues, we slowly realize Motome's motivations for going to the clan. He may have initially had ulterior motives but we end up deeming his actions as justified and the actions of the Iyi clan dogmatic, ruthless, and unnecessary. We stop agreeing with the Iyi clan when we realize that Motome was just trying to provide for his sick son and wife. When Hanshiro points out all the hypocrisy and faults the clan has, Saito looks affected, but ultimately doesn't apologize or change his actions. Kobayashi's pacifistic personality shines through when we see that Hanshiro only took the top knots and not the lives of the samurais that orchestrated his godson's death. While this movie has been taken as an offence to some, I believe that Kobayashi showed what a true samurai was in his characterization of Hanshiro. This film didn't highlight

Review title: A question in the Samurai culture
Review_body: The film Harakiri directed by Masaki Kobayashi pulls at your emotions and your stomach. The beginning of the film can be a bit confusing if you don't pay close attention to what is going on. You are lead into a very teeth-clenching moment of watching a man (Motome) perform Harakiri with a bamboo sword in front of his peers. One of the most visually gruesome scenes I have seen in a film. While the scene is very graphic, it serves it's purpose in setting up the film for how meaningful the film is to Japanese, Samurai and just human nature in general. At the start of the film, we don't know much about this man behind the "disrespectful" bamboo sword but as the movie goes on, we learn more and more about Motome and the reason behind his flaws in following the strict Bushido Code. The film shows a Renoir-esc way of thinking; every man has his reasons for his choices and every man has a story. According to the Samurai culture, Motome was a disgrace to the name of Samurai and deserved little respect. Little did the Iyi clan know that Motome had good reason for the way he was. Along with the Renoir-esc message, there is a beautiful message of humanism and the problems with extreme power. It is shown how when people are in power, they often abuse it. By the end of the film, you will have a good idea of the Samurai culture, the good parts and the bad, and it makes you think again before quick judging someone.

'Harakiri' goes from one conflict to the next very effectively. The movie is really a flashback, but shows the series of events that unfolded in a very linear fashion. Great fight scenes in this movie, and it's interesting to know that a lot of the fighting was done live with real weapons. The acting was played out very well with intensity in every character, as if most of their expressions could explain everything that was going on. I believe some of the long shots were a bit unnecessary and made the movie feel prolonged at points, but overall quite a bad-ass film portraying the eventual demise and corruption of Bushido code in the Samurai hierarchy.

Review title: Don't be so quick to judge
Review_body: This film took me through a journey of emotions. It's amazing what a director shows you or doesn't show you and how each can have a totally different outcome even with the same scene. This manipulation of emotion is used throughout the whole film and is partly why it is so great. The other feature that makes this movie one of a kind is the way Kobayashi is able to take almost a humanistic approach to a movie that could easily be made into good against bad. He does so by making us understand both sides of the equation and leaving the judgment of who's right up to the viewer. The movie kept me surprise at every angle and although it seemed slow and predictable to me at the beginning, my mindset quickly changed after a good 20 minutes into it. Give the film a chance, you'll be surprised at the life lesson that awaits.

If you're a fan of Japanese culture, and especially if you're into feudal Japanese samurai stuff, than Hara-kiri is a great film for you to watch. It's a Japanese made film from the 60's so don't expect a huge Hollywood type of movie, but even without all of the glamour, it's a very interesting movie filled with symbolism, eastern philosophy, dogma, and really makes you question culture in general and the codes we live by today.I felt like the way Kobayashi filmed the movie made it very suspenseful. At almost every moment it feels like there is some kind of tension going on, and that includes the dialogue which seemed to be most of the movie. Even with that in mind I feel the way it was filmed made every moment in the movie fun to watch. The actors where pretty good as well, especially the facial expressions in the close up shots and the real life sword fighting.A movie that I personally felt that had some similarities to Hara-kiri but in a more modern version was Rambo. Both Rambo and Hanshirō were soldiers who were dogmatic in their military ideology and fantastic soldiers. When they came back to society when they needed it most, they were treated like washed up dogs because society didn't need them anymore. Even though they were the ones whom the system created in the first place.

A "not so revenge" revenge film, Harakiri follows the story of a scorned samurai looking to right the wrongs that other so called samurais have inflicted on his family. Although i have experienced movies that have been influenced by the jidaigeki genre, never have I been exposed to one that was fully immersed into the world of samurais. Harakiri, from start to finish, had me at the edge of my seat. It was a guessing game at first, jumping to conclusions over what Motome's true intentions were and even applauding the Iyi Clan for "punishing" the imposter. That is until Hanshiro begins to tell his story... Kobayashi delivers his message loud and clear in such a subtle but powerful way that you are left thinking not only about the consequences of such dogmatic obsessions but also leaves you thinking about the master artistry that he and the actors devoted into the making of this film.

Harakiri a film that hit me in all the right places always kept me at the edge of my seat wanting to find out what will happen next. As the protagonist Hanshiro requests to preform Harakiri at the Iyi clan house the story begins to unfold. From flashbacks to jumping to the present where things where beginning to finally piece together and tension was growing. This film managed to keep surprising me all the time as the story progressed through the film.The samurai warriors lived by a serious code that by no means should ever be taken lightly or ignored.Honor something Masaki Kobayashi gave great focus to in the film . Portrayed greatly with the the image of the suit of red armor . The images of the suit resembled fierceness, pride, and much honor that could be traced back to its ancestors who wore it.Kobayashi revolved around honor in his film giving me the chance to also question it . Distinctivley showing Hanshiro a true samurai who truly lived by honor something the Lyi clan was clearly lacking . The final scene of the film was what greatly spoke to me in which Hanshiro destroyed the grand red armor . This to me was the symbol for honor itself specifically in the Iyi clan . As when the Red armor went down and broke so did honor itself . When counselor Saito covered up the devastation and dishonor that was made in the Iyi house.I felt the armor lost its meaning, its definition of honor it had been shamed. Honor is something one cannot see but something one believes in almost like religion. This was something Kobayashi was able to actually portray with once again showing the image of the grand red armor .After it's downfall which to me just showed that from that point on the Iyi clan and those who believed in them were believing in a lie full of dishonor.

Hara-Kiri Directed by Masaki Kobayashi A courageous story about an unemployed samurai fighting for the honor of his son-in-law, daughter and grandson. The way the story unfolds keeps the audience in a constant state of gripping suspense. The story is weaved together from present-time to flashbacks that slowly (making it all the more suspenseful) reveal the true reason as to why Hanshiro wants to commit Hara-Kiri before the Lyi Clan.In this film, I especially loved the cinematography. As the camera silently glides through the grounds of the Lyi Clan, I felt as though I was a samurai. From the stealth-like camera movement, to the very clean and groomed framing of the actors and the background, to the quiet moments spent waiting for the Hon. Elder to respond to Hanshiro's declaration that, "he is free to choose a second" I felt as though I was a member of the Lyi Clan waiting for Hon. Elder to make his decision.I think Kobayashi's story of the samurai culture is extremely relatable to many issues we find in today's society. I found many parallels between Kobayashi's depiction of the samurai culture and religious institutions. For my purposes here, I will use Catholicism as an example. However, Catholicism/Christianity is far from the only religion one could find parallels.In Hara-kiri, the rigid samurai culture adheres to a strict code - the boshido code. However, the way these codes are appropriated leads to abuse of power and corruption. Kobayashi relays this message by focusing on one needle in the haystack - our protagonist Hanshiro. Through his experience, we understand the consequences of these appropriations on a personal level. We see how the samurai culture was full of exclusivity and allowed for their own people to live in poverty and starve to death in exchange for the preservation of their codes. Motome, Hanshiro's son-in-law, was forced to perform Hara-Kiri using a bamboo sword. He pleaded for a few more days before he committed suicide, but they would not listen. The event becomes even more tragic as we discover that the sword was bamboo because he sold the original to save his ailing wife and child.So how does all of this relate to Catholicism? Similar to the samurai culture's strict principles and ideals, Catholicism has a dogmatic, literal and archaic view point on homosexuality and abortion. The Catholic religion bans gay marriage and refuses to acknowledge, support, or accept homosexual relationships within the church. Recently, NPR did a report about a man who applied for a job in a Catholic school. He met all of the credentials, and they were so pleased with his interview he was hired. However, when he filled out his paperwork, he revealed his husband as a significant other. He was quickly informed he no longer could be employed, because they did not condone gay marriage. And what was the position he applied for, you ask? He applied to be a cook! This story is littered with hypocrisy, judgment, exclusivity, and discrimination. In their determination to preserve these archaic beliefs, they have exemplified hate. Or the fact that Catholic gay couples are having to worship in a separate church. What the church fails to realize is that in order to preserve their doctrine's literal meaning, they are violating the core values that are the foundation of their religion.In the end of Hara-Kiri, Saito tells a member of the Lyi Clan the story of what will end up in their history books. He does not want his Clan shamed by the incidents that have just happened. Ultimately, despite honesty being the core value of the boshido code and samurai culture, Saito breaks it to preserve the reputation and power of the Lyi Clan.This is very similar to the current scandals we see today in the Catholic religion. A multitude of sexual molestation cases of young boys by their Catholic priests have occurred. What makes the incidents even worse is the churches knowledge of the scandal and its attempts to cover it up (transferring the priest, bribery,denial). And just like Saito, they too violate one of the core values of their institution - truth.I went to a museum exhibit in which there were letters encased in glass from young women writing to their local government and religious institutions. They were pleading for a way out. These women were trapped with an unwanted pregnancy and stranded without any options. I remember one woman's tearful letter as she begged for her governor to grant her permission to have an abortion. If her school found out she was pregnant, she would be kicked out of nursing school. She was the first in her family to go to school and her father would disown her if he found out.Again, another example of how religion has violated their ethical code in order to preserve the sanctity of their institution. Instead of helping these women and looking beyond the text, they left them stranded and forced them to follow through with their unfortunate predicament alone. This is exactly what happened to Motome when he went to the Lyi Clan to plead for money for his dying family.

The way Masaki Kobayashi filmed this movie was unlike anything I've ever seen. At the beginning we are introduced to a young samurai who is now a ronin, Tsugumo Hanshirō, who comes to the house of the Iyi Clan asking permission to perform Harakiri on his property. The clan becomes very angry when they discuss whether they should let him or not, knowing that many ronin have gone to many clans asking to perform harakiri, with no intentions of doing so, but instead getting sent away with some money. Believing that young Hanshirō had no intention of harakiri, and just wanted money, they granted him his wish to preform the sacred act on their land. Now you can see how distraught Tsugumo looks, and we almost feel happy. They caught him in his shameful act, now making him commit suicide seems almost justifiable instead of downright cruel. Tsugumo begs them for just a day or two, he swears he'll come back but now the samurais are set on teaching this disgraceful samurai a lesson and won't let him leave, even when they discover his swords are wooden. It's shocking, but you feel the need to side with the Iyi Clan, believing what they did is justifiable. Then, as the story goes on, we come to realize Tsugumo came there as a last resort, looking for any way to save his dying wife and dying child. He sold his swords, an ultimate form of disgrace in this culture, to help feed them and take care of them. He would do anything for them, even risk his life and his honor. Showing us that even though samurais live and die by the Bushido code, there are things that take precedence over that, like family and love. This film is a great example of that, and was directed beautifully.

I cannot stress how perfect this film is. From the style, the deft direction, to the moral yet humanistic storyline, this is as perfect as a film can get. Harakiri, in one word, is a masterpiece of cinema.We are told a tale of set in post-Tokugawa Japan, where samurai are, for the most par, ronin (without a master), and who are struggling to find meaning and employment when their way of life is upended and their services are no longer needed. These are men who are facing a new world, and most importantly, trying to maintain their dignity in the face of such change. The story starts as the protagonist, Hanshiro, enters the Iyi house to request a place to commit seppuku – the traditional samurai suicide/self-sacrifice. He is greeted by Saito, the counselor, who wants to ensure that Hanshiro is fully aware of his choice and that he is committed to fulfilling his stated desire, as there have been a number of samurai without homes and employment who were simply looking for a hand-out or pity, and therefore, new lives within the Iyi house. After telling of a recent event involving Motome, we are set up for a revealing, unexpected and devastating middle and final act. Without revealing the remaining story, what I will focus on is how the beauty of this film is achieved through the simple yet engaging story. This is a film about samurai, but more so it is a film about how dogma and rigidity is destructive once people choose the status quo and institutional boundaries over humanity and compassion. We are asked to question when and why certain beliefs should give way to mercy, and how a lack of mercy turns such honorable views and institutions into harsh and hypocritical systems that lack understanding and self- reflection/introspection. Like all great films, the story goes beyond what is portrayed and is an indictment of human institutions and societal guidelines. You aren't left simply questioning the actions of the samurai, but rather questioning one's own morals and value systems.

The year is 1630. The Tokugawa are ruling and have brought with them a time of peace and tranquility. However,this new peaceful society came at the expense of the Samurai Class, the warrior sect in Japan. As it was a time of peace, violence and battles were hardly a matter of importance and this resulted in the unemployment of the Samurai Class. The Ronin were struggling to make end meet as their feudal lords either went broke or abandoned them.Hara Kiri directed by the great Masaki Kobayashi portrays the story of Ronin Hanshiro and his son-in-law Motome. Told in a complex chronological order, as the movie switches between narrators and flashbacks, the movie shines light on the set of codes that the samurai live by, the Bushido Codes. It forces the audience to take a side on the ethics, or lack thereof depending on your stand on the matter, of the Bushido Codes. Kobayashi did a brilliant job portraying the protagonist, Hanshiro as sensitive and well,a heartbroken samurai who decides to perform Seppuku (the act of a samurai stabbing himself with his own sword driving said sword across and upward his torso) in the yard of the Iyi Clan. As revolting as this may sound, dying in this manner was seen as honorable and a privilege. He utilized Hanshiro's emotional weakness and his warrior strength to question the ethics of the Bushido code in a elegant manner. Hanshiro's uses his anger as a carefully honed weapon to avenge his family and I didn't even see it coming. The plot was taut with suspense and curiosity until Kobayashi introduces Counselor Saito, the head of the Iyi Clan. Character development is evident in each and every character in the movie and contributes to the theme in the movie: the corruption of the authority. Power.Greed. The misinterpretation of honor. The misinterpretation of the Bushido Codes. The story of Motome and Hanshiro is told in a way that forces the audience to change their perspective. In a way, the audience, is also going through character development,as our opinions of the characters change drastically at various stages in the movie.What we may have assumed may tell more about us than the characters. That's what I loved most about the movie, how we are able to make judgments without a moment pause, how it may not even make sense or follow any logic, but we still make assumptions about someone and their life.This was a great samurai movie, not your usual martial arts extravaganza, though the Boss Fight at the end was glorious in its close-ups and dramatic performance. Honestly, it's quite hard to forget, as the characters leave a mark on you and the theme will leave you questioning history and what makes true honor.

I want to make mine the words of another reviewer:"There are good, very good, and even great movies. But among them there are just a few that go beyond great. They belong to the league of their own. Masaki Kobayashi's "Harakiri" aka "Seppuku" is one of them. The film of rare power and humanism, of highest artistic achievements, profoundly moving, tragic like the best Shakespeare's plays, universal and timeless even if it takes place in the faraway country of 1630 [...] A Masterpiece, one of the best movies ever made, "Harakiri" deserves all its praise" I think that Harakiri is one of the greatest pieces of drama ever written (the reference to Shakespeare is very appropriate). The drama unfolds slowly but with incredible force and ever-increasing tension. But besides involving us in the tragic fate of the characters, Kobayashi denounces the hypocrisy and corruption behind the so often idealized "honor" of the Samurai. And in doing so, he also reflects on modern-day Japan's society, where appearance is what matters, and cover-up is the solution to all the problems. In a similar vein, see also "Rebellion" aka "Samurai Rebellion" (1967), another great movie by Kobayashi.As a frequent reader of IMDb, I see lots of good movies rated with 10 stars. I would reserve that rating to just a handful of movies that are above even the great movies. Harakiri is one of them.

This was the first film by Kobayashi that I had the great pleasure of watching. It is methodically paced, and creeps up on you, like the Mifune character does to the lordly samurai in the film. So expertly crafted it defies my trying to capsulize it. The beauty of Kobayashi's work is the basis in reality, his stories and characters are breathing portraits. The bad guys are not acting out of evil, but just working through their interpretation of honor. The good guys are not so perfect, they lie, cheat and set traps. The plot is almost Western in it's structure, a very easy film to follow, but a film that makes you feel educated and cultured. I was completely floored by the opening scene of "Hara-Kiri." It is still perhaps one of the three or four most influential pieces of cinema I have experienced. Remaining shocking for me, to this day. The fight in the windswept fields of grass is spectacular. Watch Samurai Rebellion, Kwaiden, and the Human Condition Series. Why Kobayashi isn't more written about I don't know. When I first saw this film I wrote a letter to the director, c/o the Japanese Directors Guild, it was returned months later, saying I had missed his passing away by three months. I highly recommend this picture.

This movie is different from other samurai movies, because it criticizes the samurai code; Bushido, and doesn't romanticize it. Seppuku I don't know if this is the best samurai project ever brought to screen, but I'm willing to bet that it is right up there. Actually billed as an anti-samurai film, this bare-bones black & white drama cuts to the core of the samurai way of life in an examination of the validity of the samurai code. Although the code ultimately stands up to close scrutiny, albeit unsteadily, it is finally only through revisionist manipulation that it does hold up at all. In short, the way of the samurai, or bushido, finally just survives this anti-samurai treatment, teetering upon a shaky foundation made up of lies perpetrated through sheer force of authoritarian pronouncement and will. This not only demonstrates how the myth and mystique of bushido survive, but it also gives good insight into the way those in power can turn fact into accepted self-serving fiction. As an aside, while watching Harakiri, Eastwood's High Plains Drifter, an American anti-western that performs a similar function of undercutting the perceived code, the collective bravado, of the gun-slinging West, kept coming to mind. That's another one I must watch again.

Review title: This is the best character study & Samurai movie ever made.
Review_body: I have seen this movie numerous times (at least 10, probably many more), and enjoy it each time.  The first couple of times I saw it was right after it came out.  It did not have sub-titles, and as my Japanese is not very good, I made some assumptions about the characters, relationships, the plot,etc. When I saw it with sub-titles, I was surprised at how few incorrect assumptions I had made.  That I made so few errors is no credit to me, but rather to how well the plot, character development, character relationships, and the overall movie were done.The movie is not limited to feudal Japan, for it transcends this era.  It has lessons, for those who look for this in art.  For instance, just one example occurs to me now:  It underscores the need for a person to stand on principle, and to maintain their honor, ethics, and dignity, even when those who are the political leaders have long since lost theirs.  However for purely entertainment value, the realism, suspense, art, and action could not be better. Words fail to express how this film captivates and entertains. Few films can equal this one.  It is a "must see."

The acting is powerful, the script is very tight, with plot twists with and tension that is palpable.Set in Feudal 17th Century Japan, a poor, vagrant ronin approaches a powerful house to request to commit ritual seppuku before the lord of the house so that he can die with honor. Just like the sharp edges of shadows on a cloudless summer day, Harakiri is a beautiful play of surprising contrasts that will unravel, slowly, towards a realistic depiction of the frail human condition, while emphasizing the complete lack of honor in an apparently honorable society. The relaxing atmosphere created from early in the film, defined by the calm weather, smooth camera movements, and pleasant static shots will soon be overshadowed by inner tensions and profound feelings, creating a well-defined contrast that won't dissipate for almost the entire duration of the plot.Harakiri dives into the implications of sudden political landscape change. A change that profoundly affects its characters and more specifically the Samurai class. After endless conflicts, a widespread peace has established in the country. The Edo period has begun some 30 years ago and many samurais had become masterless. Without a master to serve they become Ronins, wanderers, struggling to persevere in a world they are not prepared for. While adapting to a new lifestyle, their moral code is slowly being exposed, shown for what it truly is.Self-deceiving and ignorant, the few samurais that still have a master, walk on a rigid and intricate political maze, distorting everlasting truths and morals for self-benefit and for appearances. Living in an age without any conflict or war, they struggle to sustain their image through questionable ethics, ignoring obvious truths or even worse, being completely blind to them.Trying to be true to himself, the main character is forced by the surroundings to progress, mature and eventually accept reality. He descends, resolute and decisive to bring forth an incredible catharsis by revealing with crystal clarity that the "Thing, we all call samurai honor is ultimately a facade", bringing ultimate judgement and showing how idealistic and relative honor can be.The word "Honor" is used 17 times within this movie, but not even once did it represent its true meaning.Everything unfolds supported by gorgeous aesthetic visuals fusing with an exceptionally well told story, complex characters and music that amplifies the tension to perfection. Japanese architecture never lacked in beauty, surprising with its minimalism, straight sharp lines and symmetry. Being well aware of this, Masaki Kobayashi made sure that every shot was perfectly composed and every element used to its full extent.Harakiri tells a story whose motifs have a deeply instilled permanence that will never become redundant as long as politics and pride continue to exist. It also recalls the frail human condition but it does it so well and with such sheer intensity and realism that it feels just like life itself in the end.

Review title: Arguably the greatest samurai film ever
Review_body: "In times of peace, the honored warrior is no longer in demand." The Battle of Sekigahara in 1600 was the last major war for the samurai. When Ieyasu Tokugawa brought peace to Japan (by conquering all his enemies), the role of the samurai changed forever. Thousands of samurai lost their jobs and were forced to make a living off of the battle field. Many chose honorable suicide over a meager existence. The samurai's sword thusly became a symbol of past greatness and no longer afforded him elite status. The relatively few samurai who remained employed supposedly lived by the samurai code, but without ever having seen war. This movie takes place in 1630 with impoverished war-veteran Hanshiro (Tatsuya Nakadai) paying a visit to a local estate, where he seems bent on committing harakiri...

Review title: An Astonishing Masterpiece in Japanese Filmmaking
Review_body: Harakiri is one of the most underrated and astonishing Japanese films in history. While many consider Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai to be the greatest Samurai film in history, many true enthusiasts believe this honour belongs to Kobayashi's Harakiri. A film which has not received as much attention due to its limited release in North America, is now gaining attention due to its tremendous criterion collection release.It is an astounding masterpiece telling the story of an aging samurai on his quest to commit Seppuku (Harakiri). With storytelling and cinematography light years ahead of its time, it is difficult to leave this movie without a greater love for film and the filmmaking process. One of the few movies that will truly give you a full appreciation for the Samurai art form. An astonishing masterpiece is every sense of the word.
A really impressive study on the hypocrisy of the samourai code.It has good acting, katana fighting, amazing camera. A perfect movie.

As a big fan in Japanese culture, I think that Harakiri is a great movie. It clearly shows how the Bushido, the way of samurai, works in the ancient Japan. Besides, the architecture and the clothing in the movie vividly give us an image of ancient Japan. The most important is that the movie let us know about the contradiction between the obligation of a samurai and the humanity. Before I saw this movie, I only knew that harakiri was a kind of suicide for the samurais to show their faith and I thought that it is more like a documentary talking about the harakiri. However, it was completely different as I thought. The main story took place in Edo period. At the beginning, Hanshiro Tsugumo, a ronin went to House of Iyi in order to commit harakiri. Then the movie basically told two stories. The main one is about Hanshiro Tsugumo, and the other one is about his son-in-law, Motome Chijiiwa. Both two stories told us about the bad situation of the ronins at that time period, and their reasons to commit harakiri. Movie ended with Hanshiro fighting against House of Iyi and then committing harakiri. The movie showed us how these ronins make their decisions with the contradictory between Bushido, the obligation of the samurai and the various aspects of humanity. For example, Motome sold his sword, which represented the soul of a samurai, in order to get some money for his family. When his son, Kingo got sick and there was no more money to get him a doctor, Motome, as a father decided to commit harakiri. Motome, he made the decision to abandon his obligation of a samurai in order to be a good husband, a good father and a good son-in-law. Harakiri is an excellent movie. It not only tells people stories about harakiri in Japanese culture, but also shows us how cruel and hard it is to choose the right obligation.

Harakiri was a movie that my class watched as we were involved with Japanese literature. To be honest, I was expecting a nonstop action film; however, the movie was so much more than that. Harakiri used a genre of samurai honor to show Japanese politics and culture. The plot is about a samurai named Hanshiro Tsugumo begging to commit Harakiri (ritual suicide) in the house of Lord Iyi. There, he learns the House of Iyi's story of the fate of his son-in-law, Motome Chijiiwa a previous samurai who sought work or money through lies at the house of Iyi but was instead tragically forced to commit Harakiri with a bamboo sword after they realized his plan. As the movie progresses Hanshiro Tsugumo tells the tragic story of his son-in-law, and how he was forced to sell his real sword to support his sick wife and child. Tsugumo then seeks to send a clear message to the House of Iyi and to get revenge against the house. The plot perfectly fits in with the message of movie. The message within the movie is a huge and important one. The movie shows us the importance of honor in Japanese honor and shows us that suicide is honorable, which is completely different in our culture. The movie is perfectly delivered in its purpose of being created. The framework is remarkable and each frame allows the audience to narrow down on the characters and really get to know them. This movie was way better than I had anticipated.

This is simply because you get to get away from a classroom environment and just relax and watch a movie. So going into the movie I was very enthusiastic about going to class to watch a movie for three days. When I sat in my seat and the movie starts you begin to feel a little aggravated. I began to feel aggravated because the movie was in black and white; also the movie was spoken in Japanese so I had to read the subtitle the whole movie. Once I got over that I began to actually "read" the text that portrayed in front of me. There was multiple times during the movie it gets a little slow but then picks up very quickly which makes this movie very likable. The emotion I felt after watching this movie was one I have never felt before. It was a feeling that was indescribable; it made you think about what you would do if you were in the situation of Hanshiro and Motome. These two samurai are victims of the artistic element that the author or director of this text was trying to portray. The idea was one of obligations in conflict. This is where a character is put into a situation where any choice he or she makes will still put him in some sort of predicament. My teacher said to the class before the movie started that, "this will be the movie you will watch in one calendar year." He in fact was right and I do agree it is the best movie that I have watched in a year.

Review title: A samurai movie which is not really a samurai movie
Review_body: What a movie! I watched it knowing nothing but its title, and I think this was good for me. There is no point writing anything about the plot, actually two reviews (including IMDb's one) I read afterward reveal too much of it. I think the director would like to create a progressive change to the viewer's attitude concerning "honor" and "moral". Being Black&White and almost theatrical, it leads you to think rather than watch enchanted by the picture. It is not really a samurai action film, neither a film like "Hero" or "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" (both of which I liked so much, for different reasons), although some scenes have common elements. I know not everybody will like it, it is a bit slow and also cruel but it has a point for both. The picture was a little blur at times, but I don't know if it was the film's or the cinema's fault. Anyway, it's a 42-year-old film, so that's better than we can expect!During the intermission,I was wondering which century I live in, so much was I incorporated in the atmosphere! PS. Do Japanese people really talk with their mouth almost closed?

When Hanshiro Tsugumo first arrived at the feudal lord's clan requesting Hara Kiri, no one knew who he was. Yet, when the lord's samurais returned the body of Motome Chijiiwa to his house, Hanshiro Tsugumo was clearly there with his daughter for all to see. This is a major goof in an otherwise excellent movie. The director should have arranged so he would not be at home at that moment. I rate it 6/10 because of this. The Criterion version is exquisite and the black and white close ups are of excellent quality. Samurais are known to have beyond reproach code of ethics, but this movie is telling you otherwise... The inhuman treatment of Motome, the back room manipulation to deal with Hanshiro Tsugumo is proof that feudal politics is as bad as politics of all ages.
